subject: RE: [junit] Priority of Assertion?
msgSnippet: Point taken (and props to Yosef for bringing this up). Restating, the fact that assertion failures are implemented as thrown exceptions should be invisible to
messageBody:
Point taken (and props to Yosef for bringing this up). Restating, the fact
that assertion failures are implemented as thrown exceptions should be
invisible to users. So,

@Test(expected=WhateverException.class) public void whatever() {
assertTrue(false);
}

should be reported as an assertion error. Makes sense to me. I was about to
dive in and implement it when I thought of:

@Test(expected=AssertionError.class) public void whatever() {
//...call some code which should fail a native Java assertion...
}

This ought to be reported as an error if the assertion isn't thrown. Now how
about:

@Test(expected=AssertionError.class) public void whatever() {
//...call some code which should fail a native Java assertion...
assertTrue(false);
}

This is impossible (given our current implementation) to get right. If the
code doesn't fail the assertion, the assertion is still thrown by the call
to assertTrue(). The implementation still leaks but only in this strange
case. If we use our own private subclass of Error instead of using
java.lang.AssertionError, we lose compatibility with the assert keyword.

The optimum resolution seems to me to special case AssertionError in the
"expected=..." code and add a caveat to the documentation.

Comments?

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

Subject: Re: [junit] Priority of Assertion?



I agree. The "expected" construct feels like a form of assertion that
Junit performs after the body of the test has completed. It is
confusing that it does not compose in the same way as other
assertions. If a test has two consecutive assertions, it is not an
error for the first assertion to fail and the second never to be
called. Likewise I'd expect it not to be an error for an assertion to
fail and the "expected" constraint not to be checked.

What happens when a test with an expected exception throws an
assumption exception?

--Nat

> Kent, I agree that it is expected behavior, technically. I think you
> could also make an argument that it would be better if the behavior
> was different.
>
> In my view, the behavior is in fact an artifact of an implementation
> detail - namely that asserts indicate failures by throwing an
> exception. It could be made the case that JUnit "should" report those
> failing asserts as failing asserts, not as unexpected exceptions.
> Basically, the current behavior masks the true test failure.
>
> Frankly, I have a hunch that the best solution to this problem
> actually is to split the test in two, that is, to not mix "expected"
> and "assert" in the same test method.
>
> Cheers, Ilja
>
